member.name: T:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.AutomationEntryPointAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a method can be used as an Automation script entry point.

remarks.para: The entry points must be public, and may be static or non-static.
The method names and parameter names can be chosen at will.
Restrictions:

item.description: An Automation script using custom entry points can have only one executable action, which must be a C# code block.
If, in a C# code block, you have defined multiple entry points, you must make sure they are of different types. Multiple entry points of the same type are not allowed.

For reasons of backward compatibility, it is recommended to use the Script class as the entry point class for a script. Although this is no longer strictly required, it is good practice to add a Script class to a C# code block, even if it is empty.

remarks.para: Feature introduced in DataMiner 9.5.12 (RN 18229).

example.para: For testing purposes, you can use :

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Element.GetDisplayValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets the display value that corresponds with the specified raw value of the specified parameter.
member.param: The name of the parameter.
The raw value for which the display value has to be determined.
member.returns:
The display value that corresponds with the specified raw value.
In case the parameter was not found, the specified value in is returned.
In case the parameter was found, but the raw value is not specified in the parameter, the specified value in is returned.
member.remarks: Used with parameters defining discrete entries to retrieve the display value (e.g. "Main") for a specific value (e.g. “1”).

example.code: Element element = engine.FindElement(400, 2000); string displayValue = element.GetDisplayValue("MyDiscreteParameter", "1");

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Element.GetInterface(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the specified DCF interface.
member.param: The interface ID.
member.returns: The DCF interface or if the specified interface was not found.

remarks.note: Note that the method caches the interface the first time it is retrieved, and the interface will not be updated if it changes while the script is running.

example.code: Element element = engine.FindElement(400, 2000); var interface = element.GetInterface(1);

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Element.SetPropertyValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the value of a writable element property.
member.param: The property name.
The value to set.

example.code: Element element = engine.FindElement(400, 2000); element.SetPropertyValue("My Custom Property", "Example Value");

remarks.para: From DataMiner 10.0.5 (RN 25025, RN 25195) onwards, this method will only return after having checked that the property was set correctly.

Prior to DataMiner 10.0.5, when the value of an element property was updated using the SetPropertyValue method on an Element object and immediately retrieved using the GetPropertyValue method, in some cases, the value returned by that last method would incorrectly be the previous value.

note.para: The SetPropertyValue method will only perform the above-mentioned check when the “check sets” option is enabled.

item.description: Before launching a script in Cube, select the “After executing a SET command, check if the read parameter or property has been set to the new value” checkbox in the script execution window.
When launching a script using ExecuteScriptMessage, make sure to activate the CHECKSETS option(“CHECKSETS:TRUE”).

note.para: With this option enabled, the SetPropertyValue method will take slightly longer to execute. When a large number of properties need to be updated that do not need to be retrieved immediately, you can disable this option in order to increase performance.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Engine.FindInteractiveClient(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Asks input from a user.
member.param: The message to be shown.

A timeout (in seconds). When this timeout expires, the script will continue and the FindInteractiveClient method will return “False”. The script can then decide how to deal with this result: issue a new request, fail, or execute automatic actions.
member.exception: Failed to find interactive client.
member.returns: true if attaching to the interactive client succeeded; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: In an Automation script executed from e.g. a scheduled background task or as a Correlation action, you can use the FindInteractiveClient method to ask for input from a user.
In a message box, the user will be asked to click either Attach or Ignore.

item.description: If the user clicks Attach, the script will start in a pop-up window.
If the user clicks Ignore, the message box will be closed.

remarks.note: In DataMiner Cube, you can also use the script action Find interactive client, instead of using C#. For more information, see Find interactive client.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Engine.FindInteractiveClient(System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Asks input from a user.
member.param: The message to be shown.

A timeout (in seconds). When this timeout expires, the script will continue and the FindInteractiveClient method will return “False”. The script can then decide how to deal with this result: issue a new request, fail, or execute automatic actions.

Indication of which users will receive the request, i.e. a list of DataMiner security group names, separated by semicolons. In this list of groups, you can also specify individual users. To do so, specify “user:”, followed by the user name.
member.exception: Failed to find interactive client.
member.returns: true if attaching to the interactive client succeeded; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: In an Automation script executed from e.g. a scheduled background task or as a Correlation action, you can use the FindInteractiveClient method to ask for input from a user.
In a message box, the user will be asked to click either Attach or Ignore.

item.description: If the user clicks Attach, the script will start in a pop-up window.
If the user clicks Ignore, the message box will be closed.

remarks.note: In DataMiner Cube, you can also use the script action Find interactive client, instead of using C#. For more information, see Find interactive client.
remarks.para: From DataMiner 9.6.9 (RN 22227) onwards, it is possible to find an interactive client by user cookie instead of by user name.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Engine.FindInteractiveClient(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,Skyline.DataMiner.Net.Messages.AutomationScriptAttachOptions)
member.summary: Asks input from a user.
member.param: The message to be shown.

A timeout (in seconds). When this timeout expires, the script will continue and the FindInteractiveClient method will return “False”. The script can then decide how to deal with this result: issue a new request, fail, or execute automatic actions.

Indication of which users will receive the request, i.e. a list of DataMiner security group names, separated by semicolons. In this list of groups, you can also specify individual users. To do so, specify “user:”, followed by the user name.
Options in the form of a set of binary flags.
member.exception: Failed to find interactive client.
member.returns: true if attaching to the interactive client succeeded; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: In an Automation script executed from e.g. a scheduled background task or as a Correlation action, you can use the FindInteractiveClient method to ask for input from a user.
In a message box, the user will be asked to click either Attach or Ignore.

item.description: If the user clicks Attach, the script will start in a pop-up window.
If the user clicks Ignore, the message box will be closed.

remarks.note: In DataMiner Cube, you can also use the script action Find interactive client, instead of using C#. For more information, see Find interactive client.
remarks.para: From DataMiner 9.6.9 (RN 22227) onwards, it is possible to find an interactive client by user cookie instead of by user name.
remarks.code: bool ok = engine.FindInteractiveClient("Some text", 100, "userCookie:" + connection.ConnectionID, AutomationScriptAttachOptions.None);

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Engine.SetAlarmProperties(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String[],System.String[])
member.summary: Sets the specified custom alarm properties to the specified values.
member.param: The DataMiner Agent ID.
The alarm ID.
The names of the properties.
The values of the properties.

item.description: Feature introduced in DataMiner 8.5.2 (RN 8347).
In DataMiner versions prior to 9.0, this method cannot be used to override alarm property values that are defined in the element protocol.

When an alarm property value has been defined in the element protocol and this method is used to explicitly assign a new value to the property, the new value will only be retained until the severity of the alarm changes. After this, the value from the protocol is used again.

example.code: engine.SetAlarmProperties(200, 521655, new string[]{"Property A", "Property B"}, new string[]{"Value A", "Value B"});

example.code: engine.SetAlarmProperties(200, 400, 521655, new string[]{"Property A", "Property B"}, new string[]{"Value A", "Value B"});

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.IEngine.FindInteractiveClient(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,Skyline.DataMiner.Net.Messages.AutomationScriptAttachOptions)
member.summary: Asks input from a user.
member.param: The message to be shown.

A timeout (in seconds). When this timeout expires, the script will continue and the FindInteractiveClient method will return “False”. The script can then decide how to deal with this result: issue a new request, fail, or execute automatic actions.

Indication of which users will receive the request, i.e. a list of DataMiner security group names, separated by semicolons. In this list of groups, you can also specify individual users. To do so, specify “user:”, followed by the user name.
Options in the form of a set of binary flags.
member.exception: Failed to find interactive client.
member.returns: true if attaching to the interactive client succeeded; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: In an Automation script executed from e.g. a scheduled background task or as a Correlation action, you can use the FindInteractiveClient method to ask for input from a user.
In a message box, the user will be asked to click either Attach or Ignore.

item.description: If the user clicks Attach, the script will start in a pop-up window.
If the user clicks Ignore, the message box will be closed.

remarks.note: In DataMiner Cube, you can also use the script action Find interactive client, instead of using C#. For more information, see Find interactive client.

member.exception: Failed to find interactive client.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.IEngine.SetAlarmProperty(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Updates a custom alarm property.
member.param: The DataMiner Agent ID.
The element ID.
The alarm ID.
The name of the property.
The value to set.

item.description: In DataMiner versions prior to 9.0, this method cannot be used to override alarm property values that are defined in the element protocol.

When an alarm property value has been defined in the element protocol and this method is used to explicitly assign a new value to the property, the new value will only be retained until the severity of the alarm changes. After this, the value from the protocol is used again.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.IEngine.SetAlarmProperty(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.String)

When an alarm property value has been defined in the element protocol and this method is used to explicitly assign a new value to the property, the new value will only be retained until the severity of the alarm changes. After this, the value from the protocol is used again.

example.code: engine.SetAlarmProperty(200, 521655, "Property A", "Value A");

example.code: engine.SetAlarmProperties(200, 400, 521655, new string[]{"Property A", "Property B"}, new string[]{"Value A", "Value B"});

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Interface.GetNext(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the DCF interface to which this interface is connected.
member.param: The connection name filter.
member.returns: The DCF interface or if there is no connected interface.

remarks.para: Use the overload to make sure that you do not get the same interface twice, especially when performing a sequence of multiple GetNext calls.

example.code: Interface nextInterface = interface.GetNext("Connection A");

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Interface.GetNext(System.String,Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Interface)
member.summary: Returns the DCF interface to which the specified interface is connected, making sure that the same interface is not retrieved twice, especially when performing a sequence of multiple GetNext calls.
member.param: The connection name filter.
The previous interface.
member.returns: The interface or if there is no connected interface..

example.code: Interface nextInterface = interface.GetNext("*",lastInterface);

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Interface.GetNexts(System.String)
member.summary: Returns all DCF interfaces connected to the current interface. This is especially useful in cases where a connection splits up into multiple internal connections.
member.param: The connection name filter.
member.returns: The DCF interfaces.

remarks.para: You can filter by connection name in order to limit the number of connections that will be returned.

Like for the GetNext method, you can use the overload to pass along the previous interface. This can be useful in case of star topology setups where all interfaces are connected to one interface defined from source to destination, or vice versa.

example.code: Interface[] nextInterfaces = interface.GetNexts("MyConnection",previousInterface);

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Interface.GetNexts(System.String,Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.Interface)
member.summary: Returns all DCF interfaces connected to the current interface, passing along the previous interface. This can be useful in case of star topology setups where all interfaces are connected to one interface defined from source to destination, or vice versa.
member.param: The connection name filter.
The previous interface.
member.returns: The DCF interfaces.

member.name: F:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.RunTimeFlags.AllowUndef
member.summary: By default, C# code used in a DMS automation script throws an exception when it encounters an undefined or an empty parameter. However, if you add the following line in a DMS Automation script statement of type “CSharp Code”, then null will be returned instead:

member.name: F:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.RunTimeFlags.NoInformationEvents
member.summary: Activate this option to prevent information events from being generated by the SET statements in the script.

member.name: F:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.RunTimeFlags.NoKeyCaching
member.summary: Activate this option to prevent caching of table key mappings. By default, within a C# code block, lists of primary key/display key mappings are cached for perfor­mance reasons. To prevent caching of table key mappings, add the following statement to your automation script.

member.name: F:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.RunTimeFlags.NoCheckingSets
member.summary: Use this flag to disable checking the parameter or property after changing it from an automation script. Feature introduced in DataMiner 10.0.8 (RN 25847).

Feature introduced in DataMiner 10.0.2 (RN 23936).

member.summary: Represents an item in a dialog box of an interactive Automation script.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBlockDefinition.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

example.code: UIBlockDefinition blockItem = new UIBlockDefinition();

remarks.note: If you want to have IntelliSense in DataMiner Cube, the name of the dialog box has to start with “block”.

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBlockDefinition.AllowedFileNameExtensions
member.summary: Gets or sets the allowed file name extensions.
member.value: The allowed file name extensions.

item.description:
In Automation scripts launched from web apps, the MaxFileSizeInBytes and AllowedFileNameExtensions properties of UIBlockDefinitions of type FileSelector are taken into account from DataMiner 10.1.12 onwards.
An error will be thrown when you try to add a file that is larger than the allowed file size or that does not have an allowed file name extension. Also, the “Choose file” pop-up window will only list files with an allowed extension and dragging an item other than a file or a folder onto the script’s drop zone will no longer be possible.
Available from DataMiner 10.1.12 (RN 31212) onwards.

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBlockDefinition.AllowMultipleFiles
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether multiple files can be uploaded.
member.value: true if multiple files can be uploaded; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: In an interactive Automation script that is used in the DataMiner web apps, you can use this property to configure a file selector component that allows the user to upload multiple files. To do so, set the property AllowMultipleFiles to true.
With this configuration, users will be able to add files one by one, but they will not be able to add the same file twice. They will also be able to add a file by dragging it to the file selector.
Available from DataMiner 10.1.8/10.2.0 onwards.

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBlockDefinition.InitialValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the value that will be assigned to the dialog box item the moment the dialog box opens.
member.value: The value that will be assigned to the dialog box item the moment the dialog box opens.

remarks.para: For a dialog box item of type CheckBoxList, you can specify several values separated by semicolons.

For a dialog box item of type Numeric, the initial value has to be of format "DoubleValue;Boolean;SelectedDiscreetString". The DoubleValue contains the value of the numeric box. The Boolean ("true" or "false") determines whether the discreet checkbox is selected (true) or not (false). The SelectedDiscreetString selects the discreet with that exact name in case multiple discrete values are defined. If case you only want to visualize the numeric box, it is sufficient to only specify the DoubleValue (RN 6825).

member.name: F:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBlockType.Numeric
member.summary: Numeric.

remarks.para: Allows you to define a newly created dialog box item displaying a numeric value.
The initial value has to have the following format: [DoubleValue];[Boolean];[SelectedDiscreetString]

item.description: DoubleValue: Value of the numeric box.
Boolean: Indicates whether the discrete checkbox is selected (true) or cleared (false).
SelectedDiscreetString: selects the discrete parameter with that exact name in case multiple discrete parameters are defined.

remarks.para: Example: string sel_numericValue = "10;true;Discreet 2";

If you want a checkbox with one or more discrete values, then use the Extra property to specify a list of discrete values (separated by semicolons). If you only want a numeric box and no checkbox, then leave the Extra property empty. In that case, just set the initial value to the DoubleValue.
If you set the WantsOnChange property to “true”, then both the checkbox and the discrete combo box will trigger a change.
Optionally you can provide a RangeHigh (maximum value), a RangeLow (minimum value), a RangeStep (increment or decrement steps) and the number of decimals.

Note: From DataMiner 9.5.5 onwards, you can specify the WantsOnChange property to have a small delay before a change is triggered by the numeric box itself, in order to avoid updates being sent as soon as a single character is changed in the numeric box. See WantsOnChange.

member.name: T:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBuilder
member.summary: Represents the builder of a dialog box of an interactive automation script.

remarks.note: If you want to use IntelliSense in DataMiner Cube, the name of the dialog box has to start with “uib”.

Interactive Automation scripts resize their width and height depending on which properties of the script are filled in (UIBuilder.Height, .Width, .MinHeight, .MinWidth). If nothing is defined in the script, a default width and height of 650px by 650px will be applied.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBuilder.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBuilder.ColumnDefs
member.summary: Gets or sets the width (in pixels) of all columns of the dialog box grid, separated by semicolons.
member.value: The width (in pixels) of all columns of the dialog box grid, separated by semicolons.

remarks.para: Instead of a pixel value, you can also specify the following values:

item.description: "auto" or "a": The width of the column will be automatically adapted to the widest dialog box item in that column.
*: The column will have the largest possible width, depending on the width of the other columns.

remarks.note: If automatic ColumnDefs are specified, e.g. "a;a;a;a", and you want to show a UIBlockDefinition with a columnspan, then the space for each column will be equal, so other blocks will also move. To avoid this, you can change the ColumnDefs to "a;a;a;a;*". The extra '*' column will use all extra available space. Then change the columnspan so the block uses that new '*' column.
remarks.para: Example:

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBuilder.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets the fixed height (in pixels) of the dialog box.
member.value: The fixed height (in pixels) of the dialog box.

remarks.note: Interactive Automation scripts resize their width and height depending on which properties of the script are filled in (UIBuilder.Height, .Width, .MinHeight, .MinWidth). If nothing is defined in the script, a default width and height of 650px by 650px will be applied.

example.code: UIBuilder uib = new UIBuilder(); uib.Height = 200;

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBuilder.MaxHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum height (in pixels) of the dialog box.
member.value: The minimum height (in pixels) of the dialog box.

remarks.note: Interactive Automation scripts resize their width and height depending on which properties of the script are filled in (UIBuilder.Height, .Width, .MinHeight, .MinWidth). If nothing is defined in the script, a default width and height of 650px by 650px will be applied.

example.code: UIBuilder uib = new UIBuilder(); uib.MaxHeight = 400;

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBuilder.RowDefs
member.summary: Gets or sets the height (in pixels) of all rows of the dialog box grid, separated by semicolons.
member.value: The height (in pixels) of all rows of the dialog box grid, separated by semicolons.

remarks.para: Instead of a pixel value, you can also specify the following values:

item.description: auto: The height of the row will be automatically adapted to the highest dialog box item in that row.
*: The row will have the largest possible height, depending on the height of the other rows.

member.name: P:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIBuilder.Title
member.summary: Gets or sets the title.
member.value: The title

remarks.para: In case no title is specified, the name of the Automation script is used as title.
Feature introduced in DataMiner 9.6.6 (RN 21552).

example.code: UIBuilder uibDialogBox = new UIBuilder(); uibDialogBox.Title = “My dialog box title”;

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIResults.GetDateTime(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the date/time that was selected in the specified destination variable that is linked to a Calender item.
member.param: The name of the destination variable.
member.returns: The date/time that was selected in the specified destination variable that is linked to a Calender item.

remarks.note: Prior to DataMiner 10.0.12, this method only supports the parsing of datetimes in the format dd/MM/yyyy HH:mm:ss. From DataMiner 10.0.12 onwards, ISO format is supported.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIResults.GetExpanded(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the key values of the tree view items that are expanded for the specified key.
member.param: The name of the destination variable.
member.returns: The keys of all expanded tree view items which have the SupportsLazyLoading property enabled.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIResults.GetUploadedFilePath(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves the selected upload file path.
member.param: The key of the file selection UI component to retrieve the selected upload file paht from.
member.returns: The selected upload file path. If the specified key was not found, is returned.

remarks.para: When you have selected a file, the actual upload will only start after you click a button to make the script continue (e.g.Close, Next, etc.). Once the upload has started, a Cancel option will appear, allowing you to abort the upload operation.
All files uploaded by users will by default be placed in the C:\Skyline DataMiner\TempDocuments folder, which is automatically cleared at every DataMiner startup.
Feature introduced in DataMiner 10.0.2 (RN 23950).

remarks.note: All files uploaded by users will by default be placed in the C:\Skyline DataMiner\TempDocuments folder, which is automatically cleared at every DataMiner startup.
See also: .

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIResults.WasBack
member.summary: Returns a value indicating whether the user clicked the Back button.
member.returns: true if the user clicked the Back button; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Only applicable for scripts that support this feature.
remarks.note: To enable the Back and Forward buttons, from the General Page in the Automation App, expand Show Details and check the "Supports back/forward buttons in interactive mode" checkbox.

member.name: M:Skyline.DataMiner.Automation.UIResults.WasOnChange(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a value indicating whether the user changed the value of a specific dialog box item.
member.param: The destination var that is linked to the specific dialog box item.
member.returns: true if the user changed the value; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: Use this method to check whether or not the user changed the value of a particular dialog box item:

item.description: Did the user enter text in a text box?
Did the user select a value in a selection box?
Did the user specify a date/time in a calendar item?

remarks.note: For a .WasOnChange to work, you have to put .WantsOnChange to true. See the example.
